﻿
2020-03-12 - March 12 Update CAVID-19
Jacqueline Coe <This email address is being protected from spambots. You need JavaScript enabled to view it. document.getElementById('cloak392248bc0080a7ab5ef245b06ae86cff').innerHTML = ''; var prefix = 'ma' + 'il' + 'to'; var path = 'hr' + 'ef' + '='; var addy392248bc0080a7ab5ef245b06ae86cff = 'jacqueline.coe' + '@'; addy392248bc0080a7ab5ef245b06ae86cff = addy392248bc0080a7ab5ef245b06ae86cff + 'sau24' + '.' + 'org'; var addy_text392248bc0080a7ab5ef245b06ae86cff = 'jacqueline.coe' + '@' + 'sau24' + '.' + 'org';document.getElementById('cloak392248bc0080a7ab5ef245b06ae86cff').innerHTML += ''+addy_text392248bc0080a7ab5ef245b06ae86cff+'<\/a>'; > Thu, Mar 12, 2020 at 4:21 PM
Over the last few days, awareness of COVID-19 has significantly increased as events have been cancelled and infections have been identified in New Hampshire and in our neighboring states. We continue to rely on the state and federal experts to provide guidance and information. The public health goal is to slow the spread of the virus.
The NH Department of Health and Human Services (NH DHHS) continues to lead the State of NH’s response to COVID-19. As of noon today, there is no recommendation from NH DHHS that we close school. They were careful to say that since this is a rapidly evolving situation, the guidance may change if the risk to the community increases. We are developing plans that will allow for continuity of learning should a closure become necessary. The NH State Epidemiologist shared that there isn’t currently evidence of community transmission in the NH. The cases in New Hampshire can be traced to travel or direct contact with an infected individual.
We are aware of people within our broader community who are following advice to self-isolate and monitor themselves for symptoms because they have potentially been exposed to someone who is infected. Currently, there are no additional precautions recommended for those who live with or came in contact with potentially exposed people, unless they are symptomatic. Please reach out to your healthcare provider if you have questions about your situation.
We continue to monitor the situation and look to the latest guidance coming from NH-DHHS and the CDC as we make decisions about upcoming events in our districts. Decisions about student travel are on the forefront of our thinking. If your child is planning to participate in an out-of-state or international trip, please expect communication from the principal within the next day. There are many factors to consider when cancelling or postponing a trip and we appreciate your input.
Older adults and people with underlying health issues are at higher risk and should take the precautions necessary given their own circumstances. Because COVID-19 may have serious consequences for more vulnerable members of our community, it is all the more important that people stay home when sick. All individuals should be fever free for at least 24 hours off any fever-reducing medications and feel better before returning to school or work. Additionally, please continue the healthy practices that will limit the spread of COVID-19, influenza, and other illnesses. These practices include:
Stay home when sick.
Cover cough and sneezes with a tissue or sleeve
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth
Wash hands often for at least 20 seconds, especially after coughing or sneezing. Use alcohol-based hand sanitizer if soap and water are not available.
Avoid close contact with someone who is sick
Avoid sharing food, drink, utensils, or other items that may transmit saliva
Disinfect frequently touched surfaces
With the heightened general concern around COVID-19, our students may ask questions. Attached are suggestions for talking to children about COVID-19. https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/talking-with-children.html
For the most up to date information regarding the Coronavirus, you can visit the CDC website at https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/index.html, the World Health Organization website at https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019, or the NH DHHS website at https://www.dhhs.nh.gov/dphs/cdcs/2019-ncov.htm. You can contact the NH DHHS directly with any questions you may have at 603-271-9700.
Today, the State of NH mobilized the 211 NH hotline for all NH residents. Any Granite Stater can call 2-1-1 if they have any questions or concerns related to the COVID 19 outbreak. 2-1-1 will serve as a coordinated and streamlined process for any Granite Stater concerned about the coronavirus.‬
I will reach out again as additional information becomes available.
Jacqueline Coe, Superintendent SAU 24
